details.description: If a worker gets accommodation as part of their job it can count towards the National Minimum Wage
details.body:
If an employer provides a worker with somewhere to live, it can be taken into account when calculating the minimum wage, up to a maximum of £4.82 a day or £33.74 a week.

No other kind of benefit (eg food, a car, childcare vouchers etc) counts towards the minimum wage.

What counts as accommodation charges

Include these charges when calculating accommodation costs:

  • rent
  • charges for gas, electricity, furniture etc
  • laundry

Working out if the employer provides the accommodation

The employer is counted as providing accommodation if any of these apply:

  • the accommodation comes with the job
  • the employer (or a connected person or company) owns or rents the property the worker lives in, even if there’s no direct link between the job and the accommodation
  • the employer (or an owner, business partner, shareholder or director) receives a payment or benefit from the worker’s landlord

Accommodation costs count towards the minimum wage even if the worker doesn’t have to use the accommodation to do the job. If the accommodation is optional, it only counts as a cost if the worker uses it.

Social housing providers

If someone working for a social housing provider gets accommodation from their work, this doesn’t automatically count towards the minimum wage.

It only counts if the accommodation is linked to the employment. For example, a care warden who has to live on site has their accommodation linked to their job.

It doesn’t matter if the cost of the accommodation is taken from the workers’ wages beforehand or if the worker pays the cost after they’ve received their wages.

Higher or further education institutions

Accommodation isn’t counted when working out the minimum wage if it’s provided by a higher or further education institution to a worker who is enrolled on a full-time course with the institution.

Help and advice

If you have any queries about workers’ rights and the National Minimum Wage, call the Pay and Work Rights Helpline.
